div.h3: 5. Do not join independent clauses by a comma.

div.p: If two or more clauses, grammatically complete and not joined by a conjunction, are to form a single compound sentence, the proper mark of punctuation is a semicolon.

blockquote.p: Stevenson's romances are entertaining; they are full of exciting adventures.
It is nearly half past five; we cannot reach town before dark.

div.p: It is of course equally correct to write the above as two sentences each, replacing the semicolons by periods.

blockquote.p: Stevenson's romances are entertaining. They are full of exciting adventures.
It is nearly half past five. We cannot reach town before dark.

div.p: If a conjunction is inserted, the proper mark is a comma (Rule 4).

blockquote.p: Stevenson's romances are entertaining, for they are full of exciting adventures.
It is nearly half past five, and we cannot reach town before dark.

div.p: Note that if the second clause is preceded by an adverb, such as accordingly, besides, so, then, therefore, or thus, and not by a conjunction, the semicolon is still required.

blockquote.p: I had never been in the place before; so I had difficulty in finding my way about.

div.p: In general, however, it is best, in writing, to avoid using so in this manner; there is danger that the writer who uses it at all may use it too often. A simple correction, usually serviceable, is to omit the word so, and begin the first clause with as:

blockquote.p: As I had never been in the place before, I had difficulty in finding my way about.

div.p: If the clauses are very short, and are alike in form, a comma is usually permissible:

blockquote.p: The gate swung apart, the bridge fell, the portcullis was drawn up.
